data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: Everyone knows I’m so great:
I’m the official wildflower of our state!
You may find me by a star of blue,
or near the tail of a cat, it’s true.
If you’d like to see me even more,
go ask the rabbit at the front door.
data.answerDetails: My name comes from a Native American story about a girl lost in the forest who is kept warm by a blanket of red and yellow flowers.

data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: You’ll find me in the brush to the East,
hunting for a termite feast.
Other critters you’ll see nearby,
have quills and feathers—but not I.
Look for me on the big red ledge,
I’m a little too close to the edge!
data.answerDetails: In Cherokee, I’m called ᎤᏯᏍᎦᎳ (uyasgatli). I’m known as a symbol of strong protection and healthy personal boundaries.

data.headline: What color is my head?
couplets: Painted Bunting is my name,
My many colors are my fame!
My body has four different hues:
yellow, red, green, and blue.
Usually I try to hide from y’all
but today I’m out near the waterfall!
data.answerDetails: A traditional story explains that when the Great Spirit was giving birds their colors, the Painted Bunting was the last in line—so it just got leftovers.

data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: What, haven’t you heard?
I’m the Oklahoma state bird.
You can find me flying high,
above the herd, up in the sky.
I see a snake below me here,
And also, I see … a little blue deer?
data.answerDetails: Scissor-tailed flycatchers have special meanings for many tribes, and their feathers are often worn in the regalia of male Comanche dancers.

data.headline: What color is my tail?
couplets: I’m not your pet but I do have a collar,
You call me Boomer, but I don’t holler.
There are no other lizards you’ll see,
as bright and colorful as me!
I’m out on a rock soaking up sun.
Uh-oh, there’s a snake—I’d better run!
data.answerDetails: People may have named this lizard “Mountain Boomer” by mistake—the noises they heard echoing in the hills were more likely from Barking Frogs.

data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: Seeds are my favorite fodder,
and strangely, I never drink water!
I’m small and hiding, for safety’s sake,
behind a plant called Rattlesnake.
I live in the desert, not in the bogs,
Look for me among the prairie dogs!
data.answerDetails: A kangaroo rat’s strong hind legs allow it to jump nine feet in one bound to escape fast and sneaky animals. Its long tail acts like a rudder for steering.

data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: Wait until dark to see me alight:
of these four, only I love the night.
The open field is where I’m at ease.
The other three seem to like the trees.
I’m all out of hints, except for this one:
Coyote’s quite near me—should I run?
data.answerDetails: The English name "Jackrabbit" is shortened from "Jackass Rabbit"—so named because its ears look like those of a donkey!

data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: We’re so loud you can’t ignore us,
and in a group we’re called a “chorus.”
After dark is when you’ll hear my song,
so look at night, you can’t go wrong.
I’m out in the open, just for a minute,
go see the waterfall, I’m nearly in it!
data.answerDetails: The Bullfrog is the largest frog in North America and can weigh as much as a football. They're loud, too, and can be heard up to a half-mile away.

data.headline: How many legs do I have?
couplets: I’m a “Giant,” or so they say,
yet I’m tricky to see, especially by day.
I may be “Walking,” but only at dark,
By day I’m asleep, hidden on bark.
I’m on a tree, but who knows where?
Look by the mink, not by the bear.
data.answerDetails: They're called Giant Walking Sticks for a reason: these are the longest insects in North America, growing up to 7 inches in length.

data.headline: Which one am I?
couplets: I don’t eat meat like these other guys,
but I have big teeth, do you know why?
I’m not in the woods but I am by a tree,
Is it confusing? Come find me and see.
I’m not in the prairie or the desert heat.
I’m over by the cattails I so love to eat.
data.answerDetails: In addition to making dams, beavers build their own lodges. To keep other animals out, the only entrances are underwater tunnels.
